results.title: Maidens
results.brief_description: A compilation documentary of four generations of the filmmaker’s maternal family from 1906-1977 using images from old family photographs, slides, home movies and excerpts from historical Australian women’s films. The images trace the transition of the family from the extended family functioning as a productive unit on the land to the nuclear family and by the fourth generation into further disintegration and change into a yet to be defined form. Parts 1 & 11 illustrate the historical development of the image and its use by families in reading personal history. Parts 3 & 4 juxtapose fictional dramatic films in which the filmmaker appears with cinema verite and home movies thus exploring the relationship between filmic representation and reality. First Prize, General Section, Greater Union Awards, Sydney Film Festival 1978. Gold Hugo, Best Short Subject Film, Chicago Film Festival 1978.

results.title: Access News greatest hits 2000. Part 1
results.creator_credit: Campbell Manderson, Pip Starr and SKA TV
results.brief_description:
Access News Greatest Hits 2000 (Part 1 of 2)
SKA TV’s Access News is a grass-roots alternative to mainstream news and current affairs, broadcast weekly on Melbourne’s Community Television station Channel 31 since 1994.
Giving light to perspectives or issues otherwise not seen, stories range from front-line coverage of anti-globalisation protests to satirical critiques of commercial media.
‘Greatest Hits 2000’ is a compilation of 15 of Access News’s best stories from the year 2000.
Highlights from part 1:
Violence is Violence : Hundreds of Sydney residents take over the streets to protest car-dominated public space and offer a vision of urban sustainability. Their celebration is met with a brutal police response.
Fire Water Earth : The world’s largest uranium mine is located at Roxby Downs in South Australia. It is owned by multinational mining corporation WMC and is built on Arabunna and Kokotha land. This story follows the nuclear trail from an occupation of a WMC borefield by Arabunna elder Kevin Buzzacott and his supporters to a daring mission by videoactivists into the heart of WMC headquarters in Melbourne, surprising the boss himself.

results.title: For love or money: a history of women and work in Australia
results.creator_credit: Jeni Thornley, Megan McMurchy, Margot Nash, Margot Oliver and Flashback Films
results.brief_description: Tells the story of women’s working lives throughout Australia’s history. Juxtaposes clips from feature films, home movies, newsreels and documentaries with radio shows, diaries, popular songs, letters and interviews. Explores the challenges that face women in the nuclear age. Narrated by Noni Hazlehurst; edited by Margot Nash; music by Elizabeth Drake.

results.title: Beneath Roads
results.creator_credit: Jenna Warwick, Rah Dakota and Field Carr
results.brief_description:
Beneath Roads is a response to a purposeful void in Australia’s collective knowledge. Long before horses and carts found their way across the country, the land was crisscrossed by Indigenous pathways that remain the foundation for countless highways and roadways today.

Knowledge of these routes, their features and cultural significance is depicted in songs, which are memorised and passed down through generations. These traditional forms of navigation and spiritual understanding of place are known as Songlines. Many of the roads you drive on today are the result of this practice. One of the most identifiable pathways in Victoria navigated for centuries is the Omeo highway connecting north-east Victoria to Gippsland through Ngarigo, Jaitmatang and Gunnai Kurnai Country.

This visual poem ruminates on the layering of bitumen over these ancient routes through the lens of Australian cinema. The portrayal of the outback on screen has become one of this nation’s most recognisable cultural exports and the road genre offers one way to unpack a constructed national identity.

ABOUT THE SOURCES

Beneath Roads is assembled from a range of different film sources.

Ivan Sen’s debut feature, the road film Beneath Clouds (2002), considers the unresolved tensions of settler Australia. As two Indigenous teenagers, Vaughn (Damien Pitt) and Lena (Dannielle Hall), hitchhike toward Sydney, their journey is defined more by racism than the freedom that the road often symbolises. Director of photography Allan Collins captures the landscape as one hemmed in by powerlines and overcast skies, the terrain patrolled by cops and trampled by industry. But despite these settler interventions, the beauty and grandeur of Country prospers, captured through wide vistas and intimate close-ups of the landscape. Both Sen and Collins won an AACTA award for Best Director and Best Cinematography respectively.

Beneath Clouds and other narrative titles are juxtaposed with archival historical films about Australian road building. These Government-made promotional films of the 1950s and 60s were used to build support for ‘nation building’ and were released during the same period First Peoples gained the right to vote in 1962. These are included in Beneath Roads to highlight the lack of awareness of centuries-old Indigenous navigation and travel routes upon which many modern roads were built.

Beneath Roads further counters this lack of awareness by including footage of the Southern Warriors, a Victorian Aboriginal motorcycle club. On Survival Day in 2024, the Southern Warriors rode to Coranderrk mission to honour Wurundjeri activist William Barak’s historic protest walks from Coranderrk to Melbourne, during which Barak advocated for the mission and his people’s rights. Historically First Peoples’ ability to travel was restricted by systemic racism and discriminatory government policies that pervaded Australia until the 1970s. The Southern Warriors stand in stark contrast to this history, representing a sense of freedom, safety and pride for Indigenous communities. Impossible to ignore, the self-described ‘warriors’ travel the state Black, loud and proud.

results.title: A Good Eye for Story
results.credit_line:
Filmed in Mbantua (Alice Springs)
Equipment provided by Panavision Australia
Colour by Matt Fezz
Special thanks to CAAMA Productions
results.material_description: Single-channel video, HDMI 4k video projection, 16:9, colour, sound, 3:06 min
results.brief_description: Dylan River’s film A Good Eye for Story is a quirky and intimate picture looking at the framework for which he shares his ideas and the impact that his family, community and the landscape around Alice Springs have had on his growing practice as a storyteller.

constellations_other.name: Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls
constellations_other.description: Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls explores the reality of living in Mparntwe (Alice Springs) through the eyes of the artists, who grew up there. Place and Indigenous representation are also vital to the other works in this Constellation.

results.headline_credit_for_label:
filmed in Mbantua (Alice Springs)

Equipment provided by Panavision Australia

Colour by Matt Fezz
results.description:
Dylan River is a filmmaker who shares stories from his unique perspective as a Kaytetye man. River works across many roles including cinematography, directing, and writing, for web series, documentary, short film, and cinema.

River’s film A Good Eye for Story is a quirky and intimate picture looking at the framework for which he shares his ideas and the impact that his family, community and the landscape around Alice Springs have had on his growing practice as a storyteller.

“This film explores my journey over the past ten years of being behind the cinema camera. The way my eye has changed from looking at images as being formulaic to appreciating the story behind every one.” – Dylan River
description_for_label:
Dylan River is a filmmaker who shares stories from his unique perspective as a Kaytetye man. River works across many roles including cinematography, directing, and writing, for web series, documentary, short film, and cinema.

River’s film A Good Eye for Story is a quirky and intimate picture looking at the framework for which he shares his ideas and the impact that his family, community and the landscape around Alice Springs have had on his growing practice as a storyteller.

“This film explores my journey over the past ten years of being behind the cinema camera. The way my eye has changed from looking at images as being formulaic to appreciating the story behind every one.” – Dylan River

results.title: Access News greatest hits 2000. Part 2
results.creator_credit: Campbell Manderson, Pip Starr and SKA TV
results.brief_description:
Access News Greatest Hits 2000 (Part 2 of 2)
SKA TV’s Access News is a grass-roots alternative to mainstream news and current affairs, broadcast weekly on Melbourne’s Community Television station Channel 31 since 1994.
Giving light to perspectives or issues otherwise not seen, stories range from front-line coverage of anti-globalisation protests to satirical critiques of commercial media.
‘Greatest Hits 2000’ is a compilation of 15 of Access News’s best stories from the year 2000.
Highlights from part 2:
Fortress Goolengook : After having their camp destroyed by loggers, forest blockaders in the heart of East Gippsland’s Goolengook forest build an elaborate fortress (including drawbridge!) to ensure their safety against further attacks.
Viva Falantil : A tour through a newly-independent East Timor, still shell-shocked and facing an uncertain future. This story examines the possibilities for and obstacles to building a democratic nation.
Herald Sun Occupation : During the World Economic Forum (WEF) held in Melbourne in September 2000, a group of protesters went to the Herald Sun newspaper to voice their concern the paper’s exceptionally biased coverage of the protests outside the WEF.

results.title: Short cuts. Magic movie screens: from vacuum cleaning to Plumper's dance party
results.creator_credit: Tina Douglas and Arts Project Australia
results.brief_description:
This is a compilation tape of animations produced by
disabled artists working with a mentor. “Short cuts”
features 30 seconds to 1 minute duration animation pieces and “Magic movie screens…” features slightly longer animated works of up to 5 minutes in length. The artists include Shirley Warke, Jimmy Fuller, Terry Williams,
Dorothy Berry, Cathy Staughton, Anne Lynch, John Northe, Fiona Longhurst, Alan Constable, Valerio Ciccone, Monica Burns, Tim Williams. Curated by Arts Project Australia with the support from Council of Adult, Community and Further Education, (Northern Metro Region).

results.title: Kimberley country
results.brief_description:
Kimberley country music has its own unique style and is promoted each year through the Derby Country Music Festival where musicians from as far as Halls Creek, Fitzroy Crossing, Port Hedland and the desert area of the Kimberleys gather together and compete in the Festival Talent Quest. The Country Music Festival, through organisers such as Pam Masters (Festival Committee Member) and Cyril Archer (Festival Talent Quest
Co-ordinator), provides assistance and support to aspiring indigenous singers, songwriters and musicians. Geoffrey Fletcher, Kathleen Cox and Ashley Oobagooma talk about their background, their family and their passion for music as they each prepare for the journey to Derby and the Festival. The film concludes with performances by each of these three musicians at the Festival along with footage of the Benning Brothers, Fitzroy Express, Pigram Brothers, Gulingi Nunga, Kevin Gunn and Lucy Cox on stage. Beautifully photographed, particularly of the Australian landscape, and interesting and entertaining interviews along with some great country music.
